Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Documenting Critically Endangered Mojave Bird Songs in Authentic Cultural Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Documenting indigenous languages contributes to the understanding of both linguistic diversity and the human potential to subconsciously organize knowledge in a variety of ways. This RAPID proposal documents the last fluent native speaker who has knowledge of the Mojave Bird Song cycle. To date, there is no permanent, high-quality documentation of these songs or of the cultural contexts in which they are performed.

The project entails community-based training and involvement in the in-depth recording, transcription, analysis and archiving of the Mojave language as used in the song and of the song cycle itself. The outcome will be a standing record, carefully documented, which will benefit members of the community who are interested in maintaining this tradition in its authentic form and will be of interest to researchers of Ethnomusicology, Linguistics and Cultural Anthropology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project was to document a core expression of Mojave identity – morning bird songs – in a way that builds the Fort Mojave Tribe’s human and material resources for continued language documentation and revitalization. Pipa Aha Macav, The People by the River (Mojaves), trace their origins to Spirit Mountain located near present-day Needles, California. Mojave is a Yuman language spoken by peoples indigenous to the southern California, Nevada, and Arizona desert. At Fort Mojave, there are approximately 20 fluent Mojave speakers, all elders, and a single Mojave elder bird song singer, Mr. Hubert McCord. The project involved a partnership between Arizona State University’s Center for Indian Education and the Fort Mojave Tribe. Project goals were to:

-       Document Mr. McCord’s performances of the morning bird song cycle using high-quality audio-visual equipment and systematic ethnographic monitoring.

-       Provide community-based training in professional-quality language documentation, transcription, and archiving.

-       Build a foundational linguistic database on Mojave bird songs simultaneously with local capacity for more extensive community-based language documentation in the future.

All goals were accomplished or exceeded. When the project began, the expectation was that the linguistic corpus would comprise 5-10 morning bird song cycles. By the end of the project, the community-based language documentation team had recorded 235 songs, many of which had never been heard by contemporary community members. In the context of recording bird songs, also recorded were rare traditional Mojave songs that express the history, place names, and geographical features of Mojave Country. The songs convey stories that constitute a rich linguistic and cultural database. In addition, through video and audio recordings and ethnographic field observations, the project documented Mr. McCord’s English-Mojave explanations of song meanings and related cultural and historical content on Mojave people and lands. Importantly, this database is accessible to the community, and audio CDs have been locally distributed. The project also established a template for recording, transcribing, and archiving songs so that community members may study them in relation to Mojave language, stories, and history. The songs are foundational to an online dictionary and language teaching materials developed by the Fort Mojave Language Recovery Program. The project provided ongoing training and technical assistance in professional-quality language documentation, building the capacity of the Fort Mojave Tribe and community members for continued language documentation and revitalization.

The project represents a unique combination of community-based documentary linguistics and education. The social context for language documentation brought together community members of all ages in a broader community education process centered on Mojave language and culture. A core group of youth and adult language learners were regular participants in this process, with some learners developing different levels of proficiency in speaking, reading, and writing the Mojave language, and in singing bird songs. According to Natalie Diaz, director of the Fort Mojave Language Recovery Program that partnered in the study, this language documentation process served as a form of community empowerment, particularly for youth: “When young people learn place names in Mojave, it gives them a different connection to those places and makes them feel it is a part of them, and they want to protect it. The language empowers them; it makes them feel like true Mojaves.”

In addition to these impacts, the language documentation carried out in this project served to conserve and protect an extremely endangered language, rebuilding an Indigenous knowledge base constructed by Mojave people over countless generations. In both its process and outcomes, the project represents a model for university-community partnerships in language documentation and revitalization that can be adapted and used in other endangered-language settings.
